contentrichtext.text: {{about|the 1940s television show||Hourglass (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Television | show_name = Hour Glass | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = | format = | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = [[Ed Sobol]] | creative_director = | presenter = [[Eddie Mayehoff]]<br>[[Helen Parrish]] | starring = | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = USA | language = [[English language|English]] | num_seasons = <!-- or num_series --> | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 60 minutes | company = | distributor = | channel = [[NBC]] | picture_format = [[Black-and-white]] | audio_format = [[Monaural]] | first_aired = {{start date|1946|05|09}} | last_aired = March 1947 }} '''''Hour Glass''''' is the first regularly scheduled [[variety show]] shown on American [[television network|network television]]. It ran on [[NBC]] from May 9, 1946 until March 1947. ==Overview== ''Hour Glass'' was sponsored by [[Standard Brands]]. The program included comedians, musicians, entertaining films (such as a film of dance in [[South America]]), and a long, live commercial for the sponsor's products. Such famous names as [[Doodles Weaver]], [[Bert Lahr]], [[Dennis Day]], [[Anton Reiter]], [[Jerry Colonna (entertainer)|Jerry Colonna]], [[Peggy Lee]] and [[Joe Besser]] appeared on the program. On November 14, 1946, [[Edgar Bergen]] brought his [[ventriloquism]] act to the show. It was one of the first times that a major [[radio]] performer had appeared on [[television]]. The show was co-hosted by [[Eddie Mayehoff]] and [[Helen Parrish]]. ==Existing recordings== Audio-only recordings of ''Hour Glass'' from 1946-1947, including the inaugural show, are known to exist at the [[Library of Congress]]. Photos of the first live ''Hour Glass'' broadcast taken from a TV monitor during the live telecast, along with a program review, appear in the May 27, 1946 issue of ''Life''.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=ZEsEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA84#v=onepage&q&f=false Life Magazine (May 27, 1946)]</ref> ==See also== *[[1946-47 United States network television schedule]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0128878|title=Hour Glass}} [[Category:American variety television series]] [[Category:1946 television series debuts]] [[Category:1947 television series endings]] [[Category:1940s American television series]] [[Category:NBC network shows]] [[Category:Black-and-white television programs]] [[Category:English-language television programming]] {{Nonfiction-tv-prog-stub}}
